ygData.msgSnippet: ... With the OCR domain I m using the solutions tend to not have any hidden neurons after pruning, which makes sense because I would expect it to be possible

>
> Kenneth Stanley wrote:
>
>That sounds quite interesting.  I'd like to see how the solution 
>networks looked as well from the different types of runs.  I wonder 
>if it's possible to see the difference.
>
>  
>

With the OCR domain I'm using the solutions tend to not have any hidden 
neurons after pruning, which makes sense because I would expect it to be 
possible to distinguish between a large proportion of the 26  characters 
by choosing a select few pixel inputs that are unique to certain 
characters, mapping them directly to the output of the corresponding 
character. Where characters have common features it looks like that that 
instead of using a hidden node the networks are using connections from 
an output node back to another output node. Again this makes sense, e.g. 
in in the Courier New font [that I am using] a lower case 'h' is almost 
identical to a 'b', so a connection from output 'h' to output 'b' in 
addition to a connection that represents part of the base of the letter 
'b' will be able to distinguish the two characters.

I definitely think this is what is happening because I often see the 
best solution confuse similar shaped characters, e.g. a/e/s and b/h and 
yet there are no hidden neurons.

Back to your question then - I wonder if without the pruning we would 
see the common features represented with hidden nodes more often since 
they would not have been pruned away before other connections had chance 
to connect to them. I definitely think this would be the case - so yeh, 
worth investigating. I actually do some 'clever' pruning whereby a 
neuron with either a single output or single input is replaced with a 
load of equivalent(from a connectivity point of view) connections, I 
could try swicthing this off or reducing the rate that it occurs at

Finding better solutions seems to be mostly due to keeping the 
population lean, which keeps the search running at a decent speed. I can 
actually watch the speed of the search increasing from sluggish to fast 
over the space of about 10-30 seconds during pruning. Probably searching 
without pruning would find networks that are just as good in time, but 
as the complexity of the population increases the search slows 
dramatically. Note that in the pruning search that scored 24/26 it took 
about 1.5hrs and performed 56,802 generations in that time! In contrast, 
without the pruning, a search of similar duration performs about 7400 
gens. So increasing complexity is definitely becoming a problem after a 
large number of generations. I'm not sure how many gens other people's 
experiments are running to, but perhaps such large numbers are uncharted 
territory for NEAT?

Keep in mind that I specifically chose the OCR domain because it is fast 
to evaluate, so such good performance figures are not indicative of 
SharpNEAT as a whole :)

Colin.
